cards.back: Replacing complex, intractable, or unknown quantities with simpler, tractable ones while accepting some error. The core trade-off: accuracy ↔ tractability.

cards.front: What is the 1st-order Taylor approximation of sin(x)?
cards.back: sin(x) ≈ x, with error ~x³/6 for small x. Used when x is very small (e.g., small-angle approximation in pendulums).

cards.front: What is the 3rd-order Taylor approximation of sin(x)?
cards.back: sin(x) ≈ x − x³/6. Much better than 1st order for larger x values. Error ~x⁵/120.

cards.front: Give an ECE example of model simplification as approximation.
cards.back: The piecewise-linear diode model (I = 0 for V < 0.7V, linear above) replaces the exact exponential I = Is(e^(V/Vt) − 1) for easier circuit analysis.

cards.front: How fast does the Leibniz series for π converge?
cards.back: Error ~1/N after N terms. Very slow: need N = 1000 for 3 correct digits. Modern algorithms (Chudnovsky) converge exponentially faster.

cards.front: What is the key trade-off in every approximation?
cards.back: Accuracy ↔ Tractability (simplicity, speed, cost). More effort (terms, complexity) = more accuracy but more computation. The engineer finds the sweet spot.

cards.front: Is linearization a form of approximation?
cards.back: Yes — linearization is a SPECIAL CASE of approximation. All linearizations are approximations, but not all approximations are linearizations (e.g., 5th-order Taylor is not linear).

cards.front: Why don't calculators use 100+ Taylor terms for sin(x)?
cards.back: Because beyond ~9th order, the truncation error is smaller than machine epsilon (~10⁻¹⁶ for doubles). More terms add zero additional accuracy due to floating-point precision limits.

cards.front: What is the Taylor remainder bound for sin(x)?
cards.back: Error ≤ |x|^(N+1)/(N+1)! after N terms. The factorial denominator causes rapid convergence — each additional term dramatically reduces error.

cards.front: Distinguish approximation from discretization with one example each.
cards.back: Approximation: sin(x) ≈ x (replacing complex with simple). Discretization: x[n] = x(nTs) (converting continuous time to discrete samples). Different goals, different error types.
